### Exercise 2)
```{r}
##Create the basic model of ChildMLU as a function of Time and Diagnosis (don't forget the random effects!).

#vogue
model1 = lmer(CHI_MLU ~ VISIT + Diagnosis + (1+VISIT|SUBJ), ken_train, REML = F)

#make function for general cross validation
fold_function = function(train_df, test_df,model,x){
train_error = NULL
test_error = NULL
n = 1
folds <- cut(seq(1,nrow(train_df)),breaks=x,labels=FALSE)
for(i in 1:x){
    testIndexes <- which(folds==n,arr.ind=TRUE)
    testData <- train_df[testIndexes, ]
    trainData <- train_df[-testIndexes, ]
    model = model
    train_error[n] = modelr::rmse(model, trainData)
    testData$prediction <- predict(model, testData, allow.new.levels = TRUE)
    test_error[n] = modelr::rmse(model, testData)
    n = n+1
    result = c("folds"=n, "train error"= train_error, "test error"= test_error)
}
    return(result)
}

#Perform 4 fold cross validation
fold_function(ken_train, ken_test,model1, 4)

##Now try to find the best possible predictive model of ChildMLU, that is, the one that produces the best cross-validated results.
model2 = lmer(CHI_MLU ~ 1 + VISIT + verbalIQ + (1+VISIT | SUBJ), ken_train, REML = F)
model3 = lmer(CHI_MLU ~ 1 + VISIT + ADOS + (1+VISIT | SUBJ), ken_train, REML = F)
model4 = lmer(CHI_MLU ~ 1 + VISIT + tokens_CHI*types_CHI + (1+VISIT | SUBJ), ken_train, REML = F)
model5 = lmer(CHI_MLU ~ 1 + VISIT + MOT_MLU + (1+VISIT | SUBJ), ken_train, REML = F)
model6 = lmer(CHI_MLU ~ 1 + VISIT + Diagnosis + (1+VISIT | SUBJ), ken_train, REML = F)
models = c(model2, model3, model4, model5, model6)

#make a function to loop over models and folds
cv_models = function(train_df, test_df,model,x){
train_error = NULL
test_error = NULL
folds <- cut(seq(1,nrow(train_df)),breaks=x,labels=FALSE)
for (m in models){
  for(i in 1:x){
      model = m
      testIndexes <- which(folds==i,arr.ind=TRUE)
      testData <- ken_train[testIndexes, ]
      trainData <- ken_train[-testIndexes, ]
      train_error[i] = modelr::rmse(model, trainData)
      testData$prediction <- predict(model, testData, allow.new.levels = TRUE)
      test_error[i] = Metrics::rmse(testData$CHI_MLU, testData$prediction)
      result = c("model"=m, "train error"= train_error, "test error"= test_error)
  }}
      return(result)  
}

cv_models(ken_train, ken_test, models, 4)

##Bonus Question 1: How would you go comparing the performance of the basic model and the cross-validated model on the testing set?
predict_error = Metrics::rmse(ken_test$CHI_MLU,predict(model, ken_test, allow.new.levels = TRUE))
real_error = mean(test_error)

##Bonus Question 2: What is the effect of changing the number of folds? Can you plot RMSE as a function of number of folds?
plot_data = as.data.frame(fold_function(ken_train, ken_test,model1,10))

##Bonus Question 3: compare the cross-validated predictive error against the actual predictive error on the test data
predict_error = Metrics::rmse(ken_test$CHI_MLU,predict(model, ken_test, allow.new.levels = TRUE))
real_error = mean(test_error)
```
### Exercise 3)

```{r}
##Bernie is one of the six kids in the test dataset, so make sure to extract that child alone for the following analysis.

#make subset for bernie-boy
bernie = subset(ken_test, SUBJ == 102)
bernie = select(bernie, SUBJ, VISIT, Diagnosis, CHI_MLU, verbalIQ)

##How does the child fare in ChildMLU compared to the average TD child at each visit? Define the distance in terms of absolute difference between this Child and the average TD. Tip: recreate the equation of the model: Y=Intercept+BetaX1+BetaX2, etc; input the average of the TD group  for each parameter in the model as X1, X2, etc.).

#making a typical TD child
typical_td = data.frame(SUBJ = rep(200, 6), Diagnosis = rep('TD', 6), VISIT = seq(1, 6), verbalIQ = rep(mean(ken_train$verbalIQ[ken_train$Diagnosis == 'TD']), 6)) 

#group for only td kids
td_group = subset(ken_train, Diagnosis == "TD")
td_group = select(td_group, SUBJ, VISIT, Diagnosis, CHI_MLU, verbalIQ)

#vogue
model3 = lmer(CHI_MLU ~ VISIT + (1+VISIT|SUBJ), td_group, REML = F)
typical_td$CHI_MLU<-predict(model3, typical_td, allow.new.levels = T)

#get absolute difference
abs(predict(model3, typical_td, allow.new.levels = T) - bernie$CHI_MLU)

##how does the child fare compared to the model predictions at Visit 6? Is the child below or above expectations? (tip: use the predict() function on Bernie's data only and compare the prediction with the actual performance of the child)

td_group$avg_mlu = by(td_group$CHI_MLU,td_group$VISIT, FUN = mean )
td_group$SUBJ = "1"
bernie$avg_mlu = bernie$CHI_MLU
typical_td$avg_mlu = typical_td$CHI_MLU
plot2_data = merge(typical_td, bernie, all = TRUE)
plot2_data = merge(plot2_data, td_group, all = TRUE)

plot2_data$avg_mlu = as.numeric(plot2_data$avg_mlu)
plot2_data$VISIT = as.factor(plot2_data$VISIT)

ggplot(plot2_data, aes(plot2_data$VISIT, plot2_data$avg_mlu, fill = plot2_data$SUBJ) + geom_line())
```
